Falling-block object-oriented Fortran game, resizable playfield
Falling-block object-oriented Fortran game with resizable playfield

result.description:
* latest PDCurses if needed
* work with compilers lacking `random_init()`
* general cleanup and maintenance
result.name: general fixes and cleanup
compiler gen expr options, packaging meta
improve curses build, working on Windows Intel compiler

result.description:
* improve cmake install  package
* only static link libgfortran in MinGW to avoid possible Mac/Linux issues
result.name: static link exe only mingw, cmake packaging

result.description: add a tiny test project to help ensure that the C and Fortran compilers can link a joint program, at configure time.
result.name: CMake: add C-Fortran ABI check

result.description:
binary downloads attached to each CI run and release. The tetran executable is under the bin/ folder.

For example, Windows users download tetran-Windows.zip. Inside under tetran-Windows/bin/tetran.exe is all you need to play. The other files are just metadata and documentation not needed.

## other notes

* make program front end separate from "libgame"--a first step toward that
* make GUI tests not run in parallel with other sensitive tests as they fail
result.name: executable package

result.description: fix bug for testing that would fail on windows if gui tests run simultaneously
result.name: test bugfix: parallel gui

result.description:
also:

* use Fortran, C standard sleep that works on WIndows, Linux or Mac across compilers
* don't run GUI tests in parallel as they may fail
result.name: autobuild curses with cmake or meson if needed

result.description:
* implicit none (type, external)
* require Curses with CMake
result.name: quality, robustness

result.description:
* implicit none (external) added everywhere
* fix cmake skipping most tests
* fix cmake linkage of tests
result.name: quality

result.description:
Improve build robustness

Improve graphics/CPU use by not wiping screen each frame--use NCurses how it's meant to be used.
result.name: don't wipe screen each frame, CI/CMake template

result.description: In case Curses isn't already available on the system, use PDcurses seamlessly as a Meson subproject.
result.name: Make PDcurses a Meson subproject

result.description:
Works with PDcurses, handy for Windows as well as the common Ncurses. This involved making code more curses generic.

Added Azure Pipelines

Enhance Meson build to first class over CMake, which still works.
result.name: work with PDcurses and Ncurses

result.description:
Animated title screen

fully object oriented: playfield is an object, piece(s) are child objects with inheritance

Fixed old bug where blockseq was dribbling out to screen print.
result.name: Fully object-oriented, title screen

result.description:
First pass at object-oriented Fortran approach. 

Testing is more extensive.
result.name: Object-oriented

result.description: After this, the code is partially vectorized (except where it's more optimal not to) and Object-Oriented.
result.name: Last release of non-OO, non-vectorized code

result.description:
* allow arrow keys or WASD to be used for main gameplay
* check maximum size using Ncurses terminal size detection

These changes help lay some groundwork for an object-oriented approach in the future.
result.name: arrow keys, check maximum window size

result.description:
This allows arbitrarily fast user input response time without overtaxing display update rate.
Effectively makes updates more like interrupt-driven.
result.name: Decouple screen update rate from input sample rate

result.description:
Eliminated previous issues with race conditions in timing.
adopted "legacy" compiler selection so that non-Fortran 2018 compliant compilers can still be used, useful for avoiding accidental compiler-specific hacks.
I have not taken the time to test on Windows, but could work there too with a Windows curses library installed and pointed out to CMake.
result.name: Compiler-agnostic, robust
